answers.text: the science of the nature of man

qas.question: What philosophical perspective did Waitz hold?
What would anthropology use to differentiate man from the animals nearest him?
What did Waitz stress that the data of comparison must be?
What history was to be brought into the comparison?

plausible_answers.text: "the science of the nature of man"

qas.question: who followed Waitz lead and pointed out anthropology was a new field?
What was to be compared to civilizations?

context: Waitz defined anthropology as <b5_0>"<a0_0>the science of the nature of man<a0_0/>"<b5_0/>. By nature he meant <b6_0>matter animated by "the Divine breath"<b6_0/>; i.e., he was <a1_0>an animist<a1_0/>. Following <b7_0>Broca<b7_0/>'s lead, Waitz points out that anthropology is a new field, which would gather material from other fields, but would differ from them in the use of <a2_0>comparative anatomy, physiology, and psychology<a2_0/> to differentiate man from "the animals nearest to him". He stresses that the data of comparison must be <a3_0>empirical<a3_0/>, gathered by experimentation. The history of <a4_0>civilization<a4_0/> as well as <b8_0>ethnology<b8_0/> are to be brought into the comparison. It is to be presumed fundamentally that the species, man, is a unity, and that "the same laws of thought are applicable to all men".
